title: Top 5 Regulatory Issues Fintech Companies Face—And Tips For Staying Compliant
description: If you want to avoid fines, sanctions and legal challenges, you need to find a way to balance the customer journey with compliance.
content:
Joe Camberato is the CEO and Founder of National Business Capital, a leading fintech marketplace offering streamlined small business loans.
getty
In the U.S., fintech companies are regulated by mul… [+5841 chars]
full_text: Joe Camberato is the CEO and Founder of National Business Capital, a leading fintech marketplace offering streamlined small business loans.   In the U.S., fintech companies are regulated by multiple state and federal agencies. Navigating the regulatory landscape is a challenge. In fact, Alloy’s 2023 State of Compliance report found that 93% of fintech companies struggle to meet compliance standards, and 60% of surveyed companies paid over $250,000 in compliance fines in the past year. I believe this may be in part because fintech companies are built on the promise of a seamless customer experience. The process is meant to be easy and intuitive, so the customer journey often takes precedence over compliance. However, if you want to avoid fines, sanctions and legal challenges, you need to find a way to balance both. As we approach the new year, here are the top five regulatory issues facing fintech companies and strategies for staying compliant. Fintech companies deal with a lot of sensitive information including customer names, birthdates, Social Security numbers and bank account information. So, they have to deal with various state, federal and international data privacy laws. For example, they must comply with the California Privacy Rights Act, which regulates how businesses collect, store and share customer information. After California passed this legislation, other states passed their own state data privacy laws. Companies also have to comply with the General Data Privacy Regulation, an EU law. Canada also has its own data privacy law called the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, which applies to companies in every sector. The first step to staying compliant with these regulations is to know what they are. Identify any relevant data privacy laws your business is subject to and monitor any emerging laws. From there, you can develop clear policies regarding how your business collects and transfers customer data. KYC is a process financial companies use to verify their customers’ identities and prevent money laundering. KYC is critical for banks, insurance companies and fintech companies. Here are the three main requirements you need to know about: • Customer Identification Program: Financial companies need four types of identification for every client—their name, birthdate, address and identification number. The identification number can either be a Social Security number or employer identification number. • Customer Due Diligence: During this process, companies must gather that customer’s information, verify their identity and evaluate their level of risk. • Enhanced Due Diligence: If you have customers who are at a higher risk for terrorism or money laundering, enhanced due diligence is required. For example, foreign customers living in countries with a high risk of money laundering require enhanced due diligence. To remain compliant with KYC, it’s important to make the customer onboarding process straightforward and easy to follow. Let your customers know what information you need from them and why. It’s also important that you have a process for verifying the data you receive. Without the right authentication measures in place, fintech companies can easily be tricked by stolen documents. Since criminals can easily adapt and find ways to exploit KYC checks, you need to monitor and adjust these processes over time. The U.S. has continued to strengthen its AML regulations and most recently made changes in 2021 by passing the Anti-Money Laundering Act. This law enacted new whistleblower protections for individuals employed by financial services companies. AML regulations protect the integrity of the financial system, prevent terrorist financing and maintain public trust. The following is required for fintech companies to stay compliant: • Have a compliance officer in place. • Provide ongoing training on updates to AML legislation. • Monitor any transactions over $10,000. • Watch out for suspicious transactions. • Screen clients to ensure they aren’t on the sanctions list. • Submit a Suspicious Activity Report within 30 days of spotting any suspicious activity. You can improve your company’s AML compliance by using software to automate this process and eliminate any manual checking. Artificial intelligence can also help your company improve its ability to identify and measure risk. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was created in 2011 and is tasked with overseeing consumer protection laws. The CFPB collects and investigates consumer complaints and regularly goes after financial companies that engage in unfair practices. For example, one fintech company was fined $6 million after the CFPB said it violated consumer lending laws. To avoid these kinds of fines, provide disclosures to customers in a timely manner and make any lending terms transparent. You also need fair and objective criteria for evaluating loan applicants. All credit scoring models must be transparent and can’t discriminate based on race or gender. Not only is the fintech industry highly regulated, but the rules and regulations are constantly changing. As new threats emerge, governments introduce new compliance standards to address these risks. Fintech companies need to be able to adapt to regulatory changes to avoid fines and penalties. The best way to do this is by collaborating with regulatory officers to stay on top of these changes as they occur. Using compliance management software can also help you stay on top of emerging financial trends. The information provided here is not legal, investment, tax or financial advice. You should consult with a licensed professional for advice concerning your specific situation. title: Strategies For Effective Compliance In Fintech
description: Compliance is a cornerstone of sustainable business strategy, fostering investor confidence and long-term resilience.
content:

full_text: Anushree Rajendra Jain is a Senior Manager at Titan.   The rapid evolution of financial technology has transformed the financial industry, creating unparalleled opportunities while imposing significant regulatory challenges. As digital transactions and global interconnectivity grow, fintech companies face increasing scrutiny to meet compliance standards, prevent financial crimes and safeguard consumer trust. Noncompliance is costly due to fines, sanctions and reputational damage. Against this backdrop, mastering compliance isn’t just a legal obligation. Rather, it is a cornerstone of sustainable business strategy, fostering investor confidence and long-term resilience. Regulatory bodies are sharpening their focus on preventing money laundering, countering the financing of terrorism and ensuring consumer protection. The high-stakes environment has created a demand for professionals with exceptional skills in risk management, audit, governance and reporting to lead effective issue management efforts. With experience working in compliance roles at organizations including Robinhood and Titan, I’ve seen firsthand how strategic approaches to regulatory challenges can foster resilience in a rapidly changing landscape. For fintech companies, compliance is not a checkbox exercise; it’s an opportunity to build trust and enhance operational efficiency. The fintech industry’s global economic impact is staggering. By 2030, its market size is projected to reach $698 billion. For companies navigating this space, strategic compliance can foster investor confidence and enable sustainable expansion. A strong compliance program begins with the early detection and proactive management of risks. Creating an environment where employees feel empowered to report concerns is essential for success. In my experience, fostering open communication across teams through regular compliance check-ins has been highly effective in encouraging employees to flag potential issues. Additionally, implementing clear protocols for identifying, documenting and escalating risks—such as detailed risk assessment frameworks and streamlined reporting channels—ensures no critical details are overlooked. Conducting training sessions focused on compliance awareness has further helped employees recognize and address risks promptly. Efforts like these can help your organization address challenges effectively before they escalate into larger problems. Strong issue management hinges on partnerships that bridge departments and geographies. Collaborating with cross-functional teams can enhance the efficacy of your compliance practices. Regular connect points among teams promote transparency and alignment, enabling a seamless flow of information and coordinated responses. Consistent reporting is essential for effective oversight. Advanced tools such as ServiceNow dashboards can help your team track and report compliance issues. Structured governance frameworks ensure that escalations and decisions are well-documented and reviewed by leadership, reinforcing accountability and adherence to regulatory standards. Cybersecurity is a critical element that intersects with compliance in fintech. With the increasing sophistication of cyber threats, it is imperative for compliance teams to adopt a holistic approach that incorporates cybersecurity risk management into their practices. According to IBM’s 2024 Cost of a Data Breach report, the financial sector incurs the second-highest breach costs globally, averaging $6.08 million per incident. To safeguard sensitive customer data and financial information, implementing measures such as multifactor authentication, end-to-end encryption and real-time breach monitoring is essential. For instance, intrusion detection systems help identify potential threats proactively, while regular penetration testing allows your organization to address vulnerabilities before they can be exploited. Additionally, conducting employee training on recognizing phishing attempts and securing access to critical systems has proven effective in mitigating risks. By aligning these cybersecurity protocols with compliance requirements, your organization can reduce the risk of data breaches while enhancing consumer trust and reinforcing its overall compliance posture. The fast-paced nature of fintech demands that compliance programs evolve alongside regulatory changes and business growth. Organizations must regularly review and refine their policies, procedures and control measures so they remain effective and aligned with industry standards. Training programs play a pivotal role in driving continuous improvement. From my experience, targeted training sessions focused on areas such as anti-money laundering protocols, data protection regulations and fraud detection methodologies have significantly improved issue escalation rates. These sessions included interactive case studies, scenario-based exercises and compliance quizzes, which enabled team members to apply regulatory concepts in practical contexts. By designing and delivering such comprehensive training, compliance leaders can empower teams with the knowledge and tools needed to manage risks effectively, fostering a heightened awareness of responsibilities and promoting a culture of proactive compliance. To maintain a competitive advantage, fintech companies must integrate forward-thinking strategies that prepare them for emerging regulatory trends. Professionals who manage complex, multifaceted projects while collaborating with global stakeholders and adapting to evolving regulations will be invaluable in driving compliance success. Proactive issue identification, cross-functional collaboration, structured reporting and a commitment to continuous improvement will help your organization navigate future challenges. Effective leadership in issue management is not just about maintaining compliance; it’s about empowering safe and responsible growth. By leveraging strong governance frameworks, robust cybersecurity measures and forward-looking compliance strategies, your company can foster trust and drive sustainable innovation that benefits the business and customers alike. full_text: Mohamed Madkour is the Director of Business Development and Relationships at Mastercard EEMEA.   Payment cards that are issued in minutes, not months—that's card as a service (CaaS). This model offers a smart, simple way to meet customer payment needs while bypassing resource-heavy legacy infrastructure. CaaS is transforming industries with offerings like business fleet cards and eco-friendly payments to adaptable solutions for the gig economy. The key, however, is not just delivering on the needs but exceeding them. Today’s customers expect fast, personalized and seamless experiences. Custom card services with real-time insights and advanced analytic tools allow companies to fine-tune products, track spending habits and enhance customer engagement and loyalty. From commercial cards supporting supplier payments to consumer products like buy now and pay later, the CaaS use cases are limitless. It’s enablement and innovation at scale! Having spent over a decade in the payments industry, I've seen firsthand how the traditional card issuance process creates bottlenecks for fintechs and financial institutions in the MENA region and beyond. This challenge became particularly apparent while working with emerging fintechs struggling to launch their card programs quickly and cost-effectively. To resolve this global challenge, I'm dedicated to standardizing the current card issuance system through CaaS from both commercial and academic points of view. CaaS reduces time to market and aligns with several banking trends, like fintech (which now stands at $300 billion globally) and customer demand for integrated experiences, regulatory openness, new revenue models, technology adoption and shifting trust levels in financial services, as identified by McKinsey. When choosing the right CaaS operating model, I believe organizations should focus on aligning their approach with their strengths and long-term goals. • BIN Sponsorship Only: This is the simplest option—when the organization provides BIN sponsorship, relying entirely on external partners for processing and management. • BIN Sponsorship And Processing: This model allows organizations to focus on core competencies, like BIN sponsorship and processing, and outsource customer-facing aspects or program management to partners—a balance between control and resource investment. • End-To-End CaaS Player: This end-to-end model gives organizations complete control over the process, from BIN sponsorship and processing to program management. But it requires the most resources and expertise for successful execution. To build a successful CaaS foundation, start by asking questions about your objectives and goals. This requires creating several core capabilities, such as the following: • Business Development: Build a dedicated team to manage partnerships and capture new business opportunities through targeted marketing strategies, pre-sales support and RFI/RFP collaterals for potential partners. • Pipeline Management: Create a well-organized pipeline process for efficient deal management, prioritization and reports, ensuring a smooth transition from prospecting to deal closure. • Due Diligence: Due diligence in CaaS infrastructure involves developing standardized assessment questionnaires and setting go/no-go decision criteria. • Deal Making: Create a structured framework and negotiate deals that increase profit margins and value. Define pricing models and metrics, like customer lifetime value (CLV) and ROI, to evaluate deal structures. • BIN Sponsorship Execution: Develop capabilities for BIN sponsorships, program approvals and risk controls to prevent fraud and ensure regulatory compliance such as KYC (Know Your Customer), AML (anti-money laundering) and digital identity. • Technical Integration: Develop the ability to lead and coordinate technical integrations with partners and service providers. • Relationship Management: Implement processes for ongoing support, performance monitoring and customer service to maintain strong relationship management with partners and clients. • API Integration: Simple and effective API integration between CaaS platforms and internal systems helps customize card products, manage transactions and monitor compliance without heavy infrastructure. • Cloud-Based Platforms: Take advantage of cloud computing to scale effortlessly, whether expanding to new markets or increasing card volumes—all without large capital. • Fraud Detection Systems: Advanced machine learning and AI models detect fraud in real time, ensuring safety and reducing operational risks. • Data Analytical Tools: Embedded analytical tools in CaaS platforms track customer behaviors, card usage and transaction trends, helping enhance customer experience and identify new revenue opportunities. Regulatory compliance is critical to any financial service’s success, with KPMG’s 2024 banking trends highlighting stricter requirements. Non-compliance triggers penalties, legal consequences and brand damage. CaaS providers must ensure regional and global regulatory compliance through robust frameworks, risk assessments and fraud monitoring systems that involve partner and program capabilities for each sponsored entity. Choosing the right partners based on technical capabilities, regulatory expertise and market readiness is essential for CaaS's success with flexible commercial pricing models like the following: • Cost-Plus: Ideal for low-risk, predictable partnerships prioritizing operational expenses. • Value-Sharing: Best for growth and shared success-based partnerships with incentives tied to value creation. • Hybrid: A balanced approach that covers costs while providing shared rewards. Additionally, clearly defining service-level agreements (SLAs) ensures quality service with a framework for continuous support and performance monitoring. Reliable partnerships allow organizations to focus on core competencies while leaving technical and operational details to experts. CaaS operational excellence requires efficient card issuance, transaction processing and dispute resolution to ensure customer satisfaction. Building trust through quick, reliable service delivery is vital. Regular team training with industry best practices, plus automation, reduces errors and improves operational efficiency for market growth. Scaling CaaS operations requires strategic investments in infrastructure, partnerships and process automation to handle growing demand efficiently. Monitor KPIs like transaction volume, uptime and customer satisfaction to track progress and identify areas for improvement. Use data insights, customer feedback and continuous innovation to scale and adapt to shifting regulations, customer demands and competition. We're experiencing a continuous shift in commerce, where every mobile device is a gateway to a digital transaction. With payment flow digitization advancing, success demands clear strategies and strong partnerships across the entire value chain. With CaaS, fintechs can streamline their current capacities with future goals. Through regulatory-compliant platforms that are simple, interoperable and quick, CaaS enables businesses to focus on growth rather than tech complexities. Using data insights, CaaS connects billions of buyers and sellers through agile ecosystems. To achieve true financial inclusion, we have to bring together emerging business models and traditional markets—CaaS makes the way for you. title: Understanding Embedded Finance And The Growth Of White-Label Neobanking
description: Let's explore how white-label neobanking works and better understand its benefits and challenges.
content:
Serge Beck, the founder and CEO of Omniwire, is driven by his belief that people deserve robust and secure financial services.
getty
Embedded finance is estimated to have reached a market value of … [+7130 chars]
full_text: Serge Beck, the founder and CEO of Omniwire, is driven by his belief that people deserve robust and secure financial services.   Embedded finance is estimated to have reached a market value of $84.12 billion in 2023, projected to grow at a CAGR of 32.81% from 2024 to 2033. With 56% of businesses already offering at least one form of embedded finance, white-label neobanking is here to stay. Businesses need solutions that are both quick and customizable, which is exactly where white-label neobanking outshines traditional approaches. White-label neobanking empowers companies to launch financial products under their own brand without building any infrastructure or navigating complex regulations. Let's explore how this approach works along with its benefits and challenges. First, let's look at the rise of embedded finance, which has been driven by the growth of neobanks and banking-as-a-service (BaaS) platforms. Neobanks emerged in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, which eroded trust in traditional banks and sparked demand for more transparent, customer-centric financial solutions. With the rapid adoption of smartphones, neobanks like Revolut, Current and SoFi gained traction, offering features such as real-time spending notifications and low-cost international transfers. However, their expansion brought challenges, including regulatory hurdles and profitability pressures, especially as traditional banks improved their digital offerings. BaaS has since transformed the financial landscape, enabling licensed banks to integrate digital banking services into nonbank businesses. White-label neobanking, a key component of BaaS, allows companies to deliver branded banking products to customers seamlessly. This model has helped neobanks deploy new services faster, reduce time-to-market and scale efficiently. By 2023, the global neobank market exceeded $4.96 trillion, with forecasts suggesting it will reach $10.44 trillion by 2028. Similarly, the white-label neobanking sector is projected to grow at a CAGR of 10.6% from 2021 to 2028. These innovations are driving the shift toward "contextual banking," embedding financial services precisely where customers need them. White-label neobanking allows businesses to offer some banking services under their own brand by leveraging third-party financial institutions' infrastructure. This model utilizes API-driven solutions and infrastructure-as-a-service platforms to seamlessly integrate neobanking functionalities into nonfinancial products and services. The typical white-label neobanking deployment involves a few key steps: 1. A nonfinancial business partners with a white-label neobanking provider that offers access to their licensed neobanking infrastructure and APIs. 2. The business builds its own branded financial products and services on top of the white-label platform, customizing the user experience to match its branding needs. 3. The end users interact with the business's branded financial services, unaware that the underlying technology and licensing are provided by the white-label neobanking partner. I've come to find that businesses choose white-label neobanking solutions for several key reasons: • Deploying financial services in-house can be resource-intensive, whereas white-label models offer a more cost-effective path to market. • White-label platforms are designed to scale infrastructure and compliance, allowing businesses to grow their financial offerings with ease. • Rather than building complex financial technology from scratch, businesses can leverage pre-built white-label solutions to launch new products much faster. • White-label neobanking enables businesses to concentrate on their primary products and services while leaving the financial technology and compliance to specialized providers. White-label neobanking solutions offer notable advantages for businesses looking to integrate financial services into their offerings: Chime, the largest digital banking platform in the U.S., has built its entire banking service on top of Bancorp's white-label infrastructure. This allows Chime to offer a fully branded mobile banking app and debit card to its customers while Bancorp handles the complex regulatory and technology requirements behind the scenes. By leveraging the infrastructure and back-end services provided by white-label partners, businesses can build customized financial products that seamlessly blend with their existing branding and customer experience. White-label neobanking enables a cohesive user journey where customers can access some banking features directly within the familiar app or platform they already use. For instance, the mobile payment app Cash App, built on Marqeta's white-label card issuing platform, allows users to seamlessly buy, sell and store bitcoin, as well as receive their paychecks directly into their Cash App accounts. By outsourcing the development and maintenance of financial infrastructure to a white-label provider, businesses can reduce the time and resources required to bring new financial products to market. Ultimately, businesses can differentiate themselves, enhance customer loyalty and unlock new revenue streams. It's important to note that adopting white-label neobanking brings regulatory and security challenges. Compliance with complex frameworks like anti-money laundering (AML) rules, know your customer (KYC) requirements, and regulations under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA) is crucial, as failures can lead to fines and reputational damage. Security risks also persist; breaches in third-party systems can compromise sensitive data. A report from IBM noted that the average breach costs in 2024 is over $4.88 million with third-party vulnerabilities a major factor. Additionally, the risk of provider dependency looms large. Relying heavily on a single banking partner can lead to operational bottlenecks if the provider fails to scale or encounters financial instability. Diversifying partnerships or maintaining fallback systems can help mitigate such risks. The future of white-label neobanking is poised for substantial growth as businesses increasingly prioritize seamless financial integration. The banking-as-a-service (BaaS) market is projected to reach $65.95 billion by 2030, driven by rising demand for embedded finance across industries. Emerging technologies such as AI and blockchain will play pivotal roles in advancing white-label solutions. AI-powered analytics can help personalize financial products, improving customer engagement while blockchain enhances transparency in transactions. As white-label neobanking reshapes the financial services landscape, the challenges from security to compliance remain. However, a strategic approach to these innovations can continue enabling businesses to offer smarter, more secure and scalable financial services. title: CSDDD: It’s Not Too Soon To Get Moving
description: Organizations have been going to great lengths to disclose their sustainability practices. Now comes the hard part: taking concrete steps to strengthen those practices. Enter the CSDDD, which is all about action.
content: More organizations around the world have been going to great lengthswhether as required or on a voluntary basis to disclose their sustainability/ESG practices and risks to customers and stakeholders.… [+8243 chars]
full_text: More organizations around the world have been going to great lengths—whether as required or on a voluntary basis— to disclose their sustainability/ESG practices and risks to customers and stakeholders. Now comes the hard part: taking definitive, concrete steps to strengthen those practices and mitigate those risks in the face of disparate regulatory frameworks in the regional, country and state jurisdictions within the organization’s operating footprint. CSDDD: It’s not too soon to get moving Enter the recently enacted Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD) in the European Union (EU). While the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) that took effect in January 2023 is primarily disclosure-oriented, the EU’s CSDDD is all about action. CSDDD requires companies to perform due diligence on human rights and environmental risks within their operations and value chains. “Due diligence” entails identifying, preventing, mitigating and accounting for human rights and environmental risks. In-scope companies based in the EU and other global regions must begin complying with CSDDD new rules in July 2027. This timing begs the question: If these new rules go into effect more than two years from now, what’s the rush in jumping on the compliance requirements now? The reason is that, in short, these requirements are a big deal, and it could take an organization two-plus years to establish the proper processes to comply with them. Specifically: And make no mistake, CSDDD compliance calls for the CFO’s involvement and expertise just as much as, if not more than, CSRD compliance. Unlike CSRD, which requires transparency into environmental, social and governance (ESG) practices in the form of reports, CSDDD requires remediation and mitigation, with fines (up to 5% of global revenue) along with civil liabilities if violations are not corrected. Under CSDDD, businesses intent on operating in the EU must consider their upstream chain (e.g., raw material extraction and production) and, to a lesser extent, the downstream chain (e.g., channel partners and transportation to the end customer). As they assess the CSDDD requirements, CFOs should keep in mind the following key points. As I’ve asserted, CFOs and finance teams are taking a lead role in orchestrating the organization’s response to sustainability/ESG regulatory requirements. This should apply to CSDDD compliance, as well. As finance leaders craft a compliance game plan, they should take the following steps. Finance leaders also will want to leverage their expertise in regulatory reporting, control frameworks and validation processes, data governance, and audit trails (work that happens to be an ideal match for the CFO’s designated ESG controller) to ensure that CSDDD mitigation and accounting actions are based on sound data-driven evidence. They will need to do the same when providing updates to investors and other interested parties on their progress toward CSDDD compliance as effective dates approach. By getting started on the substantial CSDDD orchestration effort today, CFOs will help their organizations avoid the heavy lifting and scrambles that have defined more than a few recent CSRD compliance efforts.  As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to reshape industries, finance leaders are reaching a critical juncture, new research has claimed. A survey by Basware and Financial Times Longitude reveals while interest in AI remains high, scepticism over its measurable return on investment (ROI) is causing hesitation. Half of the Chief Financial Officers (CFOs) surveyed reported they would reduce AI spending within a year if the results were not apparent. The survey, which gathered insights from 400 CFOs and finance leaders worldwide, found that 78% of organizations plan to increase their AI investments over the next 12 to 18 months. Many leaders acknowledge the potential of AI tools to transform financial operations, but nearly one-third (31%) admit their organizations lack a strategic vision for AI implementation. This lack of clarity is a major barrier, with 41% of finance leaders finding it difficult to prioritize AI investments amid broader macroeconomic and geopolitical uncertainty. Even major corporations, such as Meta have faced scrutiny over the challenges of proving ROI on substantial AI investments, reflecting broader industry concerns. Despite the hesitancy, the report highlights areas where AI is already yielding results. In finance, automation is seen as a way to reduce manual tasks, improve compliance, and detect errors or fraud more quickly. According to the survey, 75% of CFOs believe AI enables teams to focus on more strategic activities, such as regulatory compliance and e-invoicing. One promising application is accounts payable automation. Organizations that have prioritized AI in this area reported significant financial benefits, including a 136% ROI over three years. title: Generative AI: Driving The Next Big Transformation Of The Financial Industry
description: Generative AI is set to be a transformative force in the financial industry, reshaping how institutions operate, innovate and compete.
content:
Øyvind Forsbak, co-founder & CTO at Orient Software, a leading software outsourcing company that employs top software engineers from Vietnam
getty

full_text: Øyvind Forsbak, co-founder & CTO at Orient Software, a leading software outsourcing company that employs top software engineers from Vietnam   Data is driving innovation in today’s finance industry. Financial institutions are sitting on enormous amounts of transaction histories, customer profiles, market trends and more. However, extracting actionable insights from such data is an ongoing challenge. With the banking sector earmarked for a 1,400% increase in generative AI spending between now and 2030, financial institutions are actively applying AI to reinvent the business model or sustain a competitive edge. As generative AI emerges, finance leaders are faced with a sea change in how they solve tough problems, think about new monetization pathways and dreams, and how to lead the game. Financial institutions are already adopting generative AI benefits, and these are getting up to scale at strategic levels. Often, traditional data analytics fail to uncover hidden patterns or accurately predict complex market behaviors from large datasets. Generative AI is a cutting-edge technology that has changed the game by providing advanced modeling and simulation tools that quickly extract actionable insights and forecast outcomes with unmatched precision. This major shift is transforming decision-making for financial leaders. Financial leaders benefit from generative AI’s capability to simulate different market scenarios. This enables them to identify and mitigate risks early. Additionally, automated risk analysis powered by AI is needed to maintain resilience, particularly in a volatile market such as finance. AI is already reshaping customer service. Whether you own a small business or an enterprise, AI can revolutionize how you offer customer support with real-time, personalized experiences tailored to meet the customer’s needs as they change. Generative AI does this by analyzing individual customer data to create hyper-personalized financial products and communication strategies. Not only that, it also boosts customer satisfaction and loyalty. A growing number of financial institutions are looking to GenAI to keep up with emerging fraud threats. Mastercard, for example, has deployed its own AI-based models to double the rate of discovering compromised cards and reduce false positives by 200%. This AI-driven approach swiftly blocks fraudulent activities and enhances overall fraud detection. Financial institutions can not only lower risks but also rapidly streamline regulatory compliance.  AI models continuously learning from real-time market data can help refine trading strategies for maximized profitability.  While generative AI certainly can change how financial institutions do business, its full adoption still poses challenges. • Fragmented and siloed datasets are a persistent issue in financial services. Generative AI comes in as a means to fill these gaps with realistic synthetic data to keep data integrity across operations. • Compliance is ever-changing, with new regulations going into effect all the time, so it can be resource-intensive and costly to maintain. AI-powered automated compliance workflows can minimize the risk of regulatory breaches by ensuring accuracy in documentation and processes. • Operational efficiency is also a significant consideration. If financial employees can automate routine tasks, they can concentrate on more strategic initiatives. Thus, operational costs will be reduced, and productivity will increase. • Another challenge is the talent shortage in AI expertise. Many financial institutions lack the in-house talent required to develop and implement AI solutions. If you are not looking to invest in building your own in-house expertise, turning to AI-as-a-service platforms or partnering with AI providers can help accelerate adoption. • Start small. Start with pilot programs to test AI’s impact on specific areas before the full scale is tapped. It means resources are allocated to where they will deliver the most value. • Foster collaboration. Guarantee IT and business teams are aligned and bring together technical and industry expertise to successfully leverage AI technologies. • Establish data governance. As financial institutions work with sensitive customer data, data governance must be prioritized to ensure proper data protection, security and quality. • Partner with AI specialists. Working with experienced AI firms for collaboration helps the implementation be quick and compliant with industry standards so results come quickly. Financial institutions must stay on guard around ethical concerns when putting AI to work in finance. They must follow strict privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR and CCPA) to nurture customer trust and avoid penalties. Ensuring AI models are transparent and explainable fosters trust with both regulators and clients, making it easier to maintain compliance with industry standards. It is important to verify that no bias is circulated. Financial institutions must employ unbiased datasets for use in developing AI models and monitor them continuously to avoid discrimination. The potential for generative AI in finance is still unfolding. Looking ahead, we should expect more advanced applications, from real-time AI-driven financial advice to entirely new financial products designed for individual customers. From my perspective, the financial industry is just scratching the surface of generative AI. I foresee that within the next five years, AI-driven insights will be central to not only risk management but also product innovation, where real-time data will enable the creation of highly tailored financial products. Generative AI is set to be a transformative force in the financial industry, reshaping how institutions operate, innovate and compete. The question for financial leaders is no longer whether they should adopt AI but how swiftly and strategically they can integrate it to transform their operations. The future belongs to those who harness AI and act now to create solutions once unimaginable. In this constantly shifting landscape, AI will be the key differentiator that determines which organizations lead the industry forward. It is now or never to embrace generative AI. Those who do will shape the future of finance.  Forbes Technology Council is an invitation-only community for world-class CIOs, CTOs and technology executives. Do I qualify?

title: 2025 Hiring Predictions: Clean Slate Laws, Identity Fraud, And AI Compliance
description: Discover 2025 hiring trends: clean slate laws, combating identity fraud, and navigating AI compliance. Stay ahead with insights on evolving background screening practices.
content: As the legal and technological landscape evolves, employers must remain agile, continuously ... [+] evaluating their policies and practices to align with emerging regulations and societal expectation… [+8376 chars]
full_text: As the legal and technological landscape evolves, employers must remain agile, continuously ... [+] evaluating their policies and practices to align with emerging regulations and societal expectations. As 2025 begins, employers face a rapidly evolving landscape in hiring and background screening shaped by legislative developments, technological advancements, and emerging threats. Three key issues are poised to dominate the year: the advancement of clean slate laws, the growing adoption of fraudulent identities by threat actors, and the progression of artificial intelligence (AI) legislation. These trends underscore the importance of adaptability, compliance, and a proactive approach to mitigating risks while promoting equitable hiring practices. Clean slate laws are reshaping the way employers assess candidates by automatically sealing or expunging certain criminal records after a specified period. These laws aim to reduce the barriers individuals with criminal records face when seeking employment, fostering fairer hiring practices. By 2025, the clean slate movement is expected to accelerate, with more states enacting or expanding laws similar to those in Minnesota, Virginia, Colorado, and Washington, D.C., which were covered in my recent article, "Clean Slate Laws 2025: Key Updates for Employers on Compliance and Hiring." The societal implications of these laws cannot be overstated. Millions of individuals with outdated or minor criminal records will gain access to broader employment opportunities, supporting economic growth and reducing recidivism rates. However, for employers, clean slate laws introduce compliance challenges, particularly for background screening. Employers must ensure their candidate-facing teams are prepared to discuss and assess the impact on adjudication during the transitional period between a clean slate law's effective date and the point when courts fully redact eligible criminal offenses from their indexes, which often leads to confusion for candidates with criminal histories who expect their records to be sealed or expunged. For example, candidates may mistakenly believe their records are sealed immediately upon the law's enactment and become frustrated when asked about offenses they expected would no longer appear. Preparing teams to explain the redaction process and offer reassurances can help mitigate misunderstandings and build trust with candidates during this transitional period. Additionally, these laws may lead to fewer criminal records being reported during background checks, prompting employers to reassess their hiring criteria. Employers should consider prioritizing other indicators of candidate suitability, such as qualifications, work experience, and skills. Employers must also remain vigilant in understanding the interplay between clean slate laws and industries requiring rigorous compliance, such as healthcare, education, and finance. To supplement these efforts, employers could explore lawful and ethical social media searches, focusing only on publicly available information that complies with applicable privacy laws. This approach offers another dimension to candidate assessment while respecting legal boundaries and maintaining trust. The rise of remote and hybrid work models has created unprecedented challenges in verifying the identity of candidates. In 2025, threat actors are expected to increasingly adopt fraudulent identities to infiltrate organizations, whether to commit financial fraud, steal intellectual property, or gain unauthorized access to sensitive systems. As I discussed in a recent piece, the emergence of "fake workers" is not a hypothetical risk—it’s a reality that employers can no longer afford to ignore. Conducting robust identity verifications will be essential for mitigating this growing threat. Employers should leverage advanced identity verification technologies that provide robust and reliable validation. Utilizing digital solutions that incorporate AI-driven Optical Character Recognition ensures that identity documents are authentic and align with the personal information provided by candidates. Anti-spoofing liveness technology can confirm that the individual undergoing verification is physically present, while biometric face matching ensures that the candidate’s facial features match their photo identification. These technologies not only enhance the accuracy of identity verifications but also reduce the risk of fraudulent activity, safeguarding the integrity of the hiring process while maintaining compliance with data protection standards. While technology plays a vital role in mitigating these threats, it must be complemented by education and awareness initiatives for hiring teams. Employers must integrate identity verification into every stage of the hiring process, from initial application to onboarding. HR professionals should be trained to identify red flags associated with fraudulent identities, such as inconsistencies in application materials or the use of synthetic identifiers. These efforts will help organizations safeguard their workforce and maintain trust in their hiring processes. Artificial intelligence continues to play an increasingly prominent role in hiring, with applications ranging from resume screening to candidate assessments. However, AI-related legislation is advancing rapidly, focusing on critical decisions made by AI. Employers using AI-driven tools must tread carefully to ensure compliance with emerging laws while avoiding discriminatory outcomes. In 2025, we can expect more states to generally follow Illinois' HB 3773 and Colorado's regulations, which require bias audits and transparency in AI decision-making. These laws aim to address concerns that AI could unintentionally perpetuate systemic discrimination if not properly monitored. As I emphasized in my articles on AI in employment, existing anti-discrimination laws, such as Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, remain highly relevant in this context. Employers must ensure that their AI tools are not making decisions based on protected characteristics, even indirectly. This regulatory trend extends beyond hiring decisions to include AI tools used in ongoing worker monitoring and management. For example, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) recently issued rules requiring employers to ensure transparency and fairness in AI systems that monitor employee productivity or performance. These rules signal a growing expectation that employers proactively address potential biases and provide clarity on how AI systems evaluate workers throughout their employment lifecycle. To navigate this evolving landscape, organizations should prioritize using AI tools designed to facilitate processes rather than make autonomous decisions. For instance, automating tasks such as scheduling interviews or generating follow-up emails is less likely to raise compliance concerns than relying on AI to make autonomous hiring or promotion decisions. Furthermore, employers must develop comprehensive AI compliance frameworks that extend beyond hiring. These frameworks should account for how AI tools are used in employee evaluations, promotions, and disciplinary actions. Employers should partner with trusted vendors who can demonstrate that their AI solutions meet regulatory requirements and adhere to fairness and transparency standards. As these three trends converge in 2025, the stakes for employers have never been higher. Compliance with clean slate laws will require meticulous attention to detail and an openness to adopting more holistic hiring criteria. Protecting against identity fraud will demand investment in cutting-edge verification technologies and processes. Adapting to AI legislation will necessitate a balance between leveraging innovation and ensuring fairness. As the legal and technological landscape evolves, employers must remain agile, continuously evaluating their policies and practices to align with emerging regulations and societal expectations. By staying ahead of these trends, employers can turn challenges into opportunities and thrive in the face of change. At the same time, they will contribute to a more inclusive and secure workforce, benefiting both their organizations and society at large.  One Community. title: Digital Escrow: Industry Challenges, Opportunities And The Path Forward
description: As this market evolves, it needs to address complications while developing a tactical plan for maximum expansion.
content:
Parvez Siddiqui is cofounder of TrustIn Limited, a regulated and global digital escrow platform, and an advocate for inclusive finance.
getty
Trust has always been essential to commerce. Silk Road … [+6326 chars]
full_text: Parvez Siddiqui is cofounder of TrustIn Limited, a regulated and global digital escrow platform, and an advocate for inclusive finance.   Trust has always been essential to commerce. Silk Road traders, for example, needed intermediaries to guarantee that merchandise went one way and payments went another. As the world grows and develops and technology advances at a rapid rate, trust remains the catalyst for a functioning global society. Where a payment process would once take weeks to finalize and delicately navigate, payments can now be made with a literal click of a button. Parties never even have to encounter one another. But in this arrangement, how does one ensure trust? Digital escrow is one tool that aims to help answer this question. This is the process by which an unbiased third-party agent holds cash or a title and only releases the payment or item due when a contract has been thoroughly fulfilled. As the cofounder of a digital escrow platform, I believe that as this market evolves, it needs to address complications while developing a tactical plan for maximum expansion. Digital escrow is a relatively easy concept: An impartial third party holds funds or property until specified rules are achieved. Here's how it works: • Conditions established: The buyer and seller determine the agreement, what will be provided, payment, etc. • Payment made: The buyer places payment in the escrow account as a show of good faith. • Services rendered: The seller provides the product/service as required. • Payment released: The buyer acknowledges satisfaction and approves the release to the seller. A key development in digital escrow today is the use of virtual accounts. These accounts can be created depending on the transaction, like an account just for a real estate purchase or supply purchase. Virtual accounts can also provide visibility, so buyers and sellers can see where the funds are at any time and cross-border flexibility. The ability to function in different currencies can make international transactions simpler. Digital escrow is used in various sectors, such as e-commerce. In an industry that reached $5.8 trillion in retail sales in 2023 alone, some e-commerce platforms are using digital escrow to help give buyers and sellers more peace of mind until the transaction is complete. Digital escrow can also be used in real estate, supply chain financing and crowdfunding, something I've seen firsthand through my company's work. Luxury goods and collectibles are another example; sometimes, digital escrow is used to secure transactions involving rare items like art, high-end jewelry and cars. Global digital escrow services must navigate diverse anti-money laundering and know-your-customer requirements, which can vary significantly across jurisdictions. Missteps can be costly, as global non-compliance fines exceeded $4 billion in 2022, according to the Reading Between the Fines Report by Fenergo (registration required). Opportunities for leaders: • Partner with regulators. Build relationships with regulatory bodies to help foster trust and compliance with local and international standards. • Explore automation for compliance. AI and machine learning can streamline AML/KYC checks, which can help reduce errors and adapt to evolving regulations. Digital escrow platforms are prime targets for cyberattacks due to the sensitive financial data they handle. A breach could compromise funds and erode user trust. This year, the average cost of a data breach globally increased by 10% to $4.88 million, according to IBM's Cost of a Data Breach Report (registration required). Opportunities for leaders: • Embed cybersecurity by design. Ensure you're using advanced encryption, multifactor authentication and secure application programming interfaces to help protect platforms from breaches. • Consider blockchain technology. Blockchain technology can help enhance cybersecurity in digital escrow by creating immutable transaction records that are transparent and tamper-proof. Depending on the type of blockchain used, even the escrow platform itself may not be able to change the transaction guidelines or terms and conditions of the escrow transaction because that will be saved securely in the blockchain. While my company uses traditional cybersecurity measures, we are working on a blockchain solution to further secure user data and escrow transaction conditions. For companies looking to do something similar and integrate blockchain, starting with a clear identification of relevant use cases, such as transaction verification or fraud prevention, is key. From there, you can partner with experienced blockchain platforms to ensure a successful implementation. The future of digital escrow lies at the intersection of technology and trust. Innovative tools and global standardization will shape the industry’s trajectory. 1. Use of blockchain: I believe the potential of blockchain technology for tracing and verifying escrowed funds could be transformative for the digital escrow space. The blockchain market as a whole is projected to reach $825 billion by 2032, according to Fortune Business Insights. 2. AI-driven compliance: Automation could transform compliance and regulatory efforts, as well as help reduce human error. 3. Standardization across the globe: I expect to see new global regulations and compliance standards for digital escrow in the future, especially since I anticipate cross-border transactions to become more commonplace. To avoid becoming obsolete, companies should conduct compliance audits regularly and establish internal structures to assess new regulations prior to relaying compliance training to employees and clients. Understanding who the leaders in the industry are and tracking governmental regulatory agencies can keep a company apprised when changes do occur so compliance can be adjusted seamlessly. Trust is the new currency, and I believe digital escrow will become more common in transactions worldwide. If current challenges—like regulatory hurdles and cybersecurity risks—can be worked out, the integration of technologies like blockchain could position digital escrow as a transformative solution in the global marketplace. title: Three Challenges Stalling AI Implementation In The Financial Sector
description: Behind the headlines, financial companies continue to face major challenges with AI adoption and implementation.
content:
Erum Manzoor is Senior Vice PresidentGlobal Wealth Technology of Citigroup and thought leader, Linkedin Top Voice, author and speaker.
getty
AI is massively reshaping the financial world, but fully… [+5915 chars]
full_text: Erum Manzoor is Senior Vice President—Global Wealth Technology of Citigroup and thought leader, Linkedin Top Voice, author and speaker.   AI is massively reshaping the financial world, but fully integrating this technology is burdensome and expensive. As Citi explained in a recent report, AI will profoundly change the future of finance and money, and "it could potentially drive global banking industry profits to $2 trillion by 2028, a 9% increase over the next five years." Heavyweights such as Citi, JPMorgan Chase and Capitol One, among others, have committed to AI investments for gains in efficiencies, enhanced customer experience and enhanced risk assessment. However, behind the headlines, companies face tough regulations, an entangled web of legacy systems and the creation of customer-ready solutions that continue to pose major challenges. Financial institutions are among the most regulated environments on the planet, and the deployment of AI introduces troublesome compliance issues that are becoming increasingly strict by the year. Within the European Union, for example, heavy fines under the General Data Protection Regulation have been levied against organizations for mishandling consumer data. Each serious breach could amount to a fine of up to 4% of a company's global revenue. Similarly, with the AI Act, the EU classifies AI applications according to risk, placing financial applications like credit scoring or fraud detection under the "high-risk" category. That means more disclosures, auditing and explainability—each of which adds more compliance and administration. In the U.S., state-by-state data privacy laws are either proposed or already in place—such as the CCPA and the NYDFS Part 500 regulation. This is a fragmented regulatory landscape that forces banks into region-specific AI protocols, driving up implementation costs and elongating the timescale required to fully implement AI-driven services. Most banks, as well as insurance and asset management companies, have big investments in legacy infrastructure—in many cases, going back decades. Although still operational, older systems are often not structured for the heavy computation loads or complex data analytics that are required by AI. Deloitte points out that many financial institutions still rely on core operations managed through mainframe-based infrastructure. With this infrastructure, in general, AI requires extensive and expensive workarounds for integration. As McKinsey pointed out in a 2021 report, legacy systems "often lack the capacity and flexibility required to support the variable computing requirements, data-processing needs, and real-time analysis that closed-loop AI applications require." Most smaller institutions cannot afford bespoke repairs to update their systems, meaning access to scaleable AI remains beyond them and is deepening a technological divide between global players and regional banks. Legacy systems also use incompatible data formats, which create difficulties for AI algorithms to operate on existing information. One challenge, for instance, is if AI tools often cannot access siloed customer data from operations around the organization, which can significantly limit a model's effectiveness. This lack of interoperability generally results in fragmentations of AI systems that cannot reach the complete dataset required for their accuracy. In such cases, AI fails to live up to its pledge of allowing advanced customer personalization and risk analytics. Creating customer-ready solutions using AI presents a host of different challenges. For financial firms, usability, scalability and building customer trust are a few of the major concerns if the technology is to see widespread acceptance. For example, AI-powered customer-service bots are multiplying but have variously suffered from everything from minimal capability to resolve problems to subpar hand-offs with human agents. Meanwhile, perfecting those tools to deliver seamless customer experiences reliably remains an uphill task: According to a SurveyMonkey report, "61% of consumers say humans understand their needs better than AI." But banks are aware of this issue. According to a report from EY-Parthenon, 60% of banks are implementing GenAI to make customer experience enhancements—one of the greatest motivators to implement the technology, second only to productivity enhancements. The lack of transparency is also an issue. This is especially true of applications related to credit assessment and investment advice, among others, where a lack of transparency could cloud any decision and affect bottom-line financial outcomes. The drive toward explainable AI (XAI), an expensive undertaking wherein most systems do a lot more than carry out complex computations, also explains those decisions in clear, simple language. And add to this the talent shortage that plagues the industry. A report by Rivel Banking found that "80% of community banks and credit unions list staffing as their biggest concern." Even for institutions with moderately sufficient budgets, the recruitment and retention of talent to construct AI solutions is hard to find. These challenges underpin the truism that while AI can transform finance, the potential will be realized only with more than just technological investment. This involves several structural and strategic changes, ranging from regulatory harmonization to the gradual replacement of legacy systems. Until then, AI in finance remains an elite tool available to a few institutions—which are capable and willing to meet the financial, regulatory and operational demands. For the rest, the transformative promise of AI will continue to remain out of grasp. Forbes Technology Council is an invitation-only community for world-class CIOs, CTOs and technology executives. title: Navigating The Tug-Of-War Between Innovation And Regulation In DeFi
description: A legal battle in Texas could shape the future of DeFi, as innovators challenge the IRS and Treasury’s controversial “broker” rule. It's a pivotal moment for innovation.
content:
Decentralized Finance (DeFI) is at a crossroads (Photo by Jakub Porzycki/NurPhoto via Getty Images)
NurPhoto via Getty Images
Don't Mess with Texas Innovation
A legal battle in Texas could shape t… [+11362 chars]
full_text: Decentralized Finance (DeFI) is at a crossroads (Photo by Jakub Porzycki/NurPhoto via Getty Images) A legal battle in Texas could shape the future of decentralized finance (DeFi), as innovators challenge the IRS and Treasury’s controversial “broker” rule, highlighting a pivotal moment for regulation and innovation in the U.S. There’s a saying in the Lone Star State: Don’t mess with Texas. Living there, I quickly learned that this wasn’t just a catchphrase; it was a reflection of the state’s fierce independence and pride. Texas, with its vast landscapes and resilient spirit, has long been a place where individuals and businesses have thrived on the principles of freedom and self-reliance. Like so many who have been lucky to live in the state, I appreciated the culture of entrepreneurship and the ability to innovate without the heavy hand of regulation. Texas, home of the Texas Blockchain Council (Photo by Tamir Kalifa/Getty Images) So, when news broke that the DeFi Education Fund, the Blockchain Association, and the Texas Blockchain Council filed a lawsuit challenging the IRS and Treasury Department’s final “broker” rule making, it hit me in a way that felt deeply personal. The very same state I had once called home, famous for fighting to keep regulation at bay, was now at the heart of a legal battle against a rule that many believe could stifle innovation in one of the most groundbreaking industries of our time: decentralized finance (DeFi). The digital asset industry, a sector marked by rapid innovation and decentralization, finds itself at the center of this legal battle, sparked by the IRS and Treasury Department’s controversial final “broker” rulemaking. On December 27, 2024, the DeFi Education Fund, the Blockchain Association, and the Texas Blockchain Council filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas. Their claim: the rule exceeds the statutory authority of the IRS and Treasury, violates the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and is unconstitutional. This case isn’t just about a technical legal issue; it’s a reflection of the tension between the regulatory frameworks of traditional financial systems and the disruptive force of new technologies like decentralized finance (DeFi). DeFi, by design, operates without a central authority, enabling individuals to engage in financial activities—such as lending, borrowing, and trading—without relying on intermediaries like banks. It’s this very decentralization that makes DeFi so revolutionary; it’s also what makes it so attractive to a state that’s always prized freedom and rugged individualism. Of course, those same qualities make central government and regulators incredibly nervous of ceding to control. At the core of this dispute lies a critical question: how should decentralized technologies be regulated? And, more importantly, how can regulators ensure that innovation continues without undermining the very principles of decentralization that DeFi embodies? The stakes in this case couldn’t be higher. If the IRS and Treasury rule stands, it could create a regulatory framework that doesn’t simply stifle innovation but potentially drives developers and entrepreneurs overseas. For the DeFi Education Fund, the Blockchain Association, and the Texas Blockchain Council, this is about more than just legal arguments. It’s about protecting a nascent industry from a potentially calamitous act of sabotage. The global blockchain revolution is too big and far too advanced to lose sleep over the “broker” rule. It does, however, have a huge bearing on whether Texas (and by extension, the U.S.) continues to play a major, leading role in reshaping the financial landscape for the better. Marisa Coppel, Head of Legal for the Blockchain Association Marisa Coppel, Head of Legal for the Blockchain Association, argues that the rule’s broad definition of a "broker" threatens to push innovation out of the U.S. "The IRS and Treasury have gone beyond their statutory authority in expanding the definition of ‘broker’ to include providers of DeFi trading front-ends even though they do not affect transactions," Coppel said. "This not only infringes on the privacy rights of individuals using decentralized technology, but it also risks pushing this entire burgeoning technology offshore." My fondest memories of Texas are from working with some of the brightest minds in the tech space. We were always looking for ways to innovate, to push boundaries, to create something that would not only stand out but also help shape the future. It’s clear that the plaintiffs in this case are deeply concerned about the future of innovation in the U.S. "We are incredibly disappointed in today’s decision by the Treasury and the IRS to finalize the misguided and unfairly sweeping DeFi portion of their ‘broker’ rulemaking," said Miller Whitehouse-Levine, CEO of the DeFi Education Fund. "Decentralized Finance promises to make financial services and the digital economy more accessible, efficient, interoperable, dependable, and consumer-focused. This promise is at the heart of our work at the DeFi Education Fund. This unfortunate rulemaking is a direct threat to financial innovation, and we intend to fight it using every tool available to us." Lee Bratcher, President of the Texas Blockchain Council The challenges of regulating DeFi are very real. The rule’s provisions impose unrealistic compliance expectations on decentralized platforms that simply do not have the kind of centralized structure required to meet these demands. "The rule fails to recognize the decentralized nature of this technology," said Lee Bratcher, President of the Texas Blockchain Council. "Many actors simply do not have access to the information the IRS is now demanding. This regulatory overreach risks driving critical development overseas, threatening U.S. competitiveness in the digital economy." A notable example of the tension between innovation and regulation in decentralized finance (DeFi) involves the platform Uniswap. Uniswap, a decentralized exchange (DEX) built on the Ethereum blockchain, enables users to trade cryptocurrencies without intermediaries, embodying the core principles of DeFi. Its open-access model and automated liquidity provision have been hailed as significant innovations in the financial sector. However, Uniswap's decentralized nature has also attracted scrutiny from regulators concerned about issues such as money laundering, fraud, and investor protection. The lack of traditional oversight mechanisms in DeFi platforms like Uniswap poses challenges for regulatory bodies attempting to enforce compliance and ensure market integrity. This situation exemplifies the broader debate within the DeFi ecosystem: how to balance the drive for financial innovation and inclusivity with the necessity of regulatory frameworks that protect users and maintain systemic stability. Achieving this balance is crucial for the sustainable growth of DeFi platforms and their integration into the mainstream financial system. The implications of this case stretch far beyond the digital asset sector. The growing prominence of blockchain technology and decentralized finance forces regulators to confront an increasingly complex question: How can you regulate something that operates outside of traditional systems of control? Blockchain, by its very nature, defies traditional models of regulation. This isn’t just about the future of DeFi; it’s about how we, as a society, understand and interact with technology that doesn’t rely on central authorities to function. Can we strike a balance between protecting consumers and ensuring that innovation continues to thrive? Blockchain is a decentralized, secure digital ledger that records transactions transparently and ... [+] immutably across a network of computers. For me, the question of regulation in emerging technologies hits home. I have always believed that the best way to innovate is to allow ideas to grow organically, without the constraints of overregulation. I saw firsthand how Silicon Valley, Austin, and other tech hubs thrived under conditions that allowed ideas to flourish without excessive government intervention. It wasn’t perfect, but it worked. The regulatory uncertainty created by the IRS’s rule could put that entire ecosystem at risk, potentially forcing talent and investment to flow elsewhere. This lawsuit against the IRS and Treasury is about more than just a legal challenge—it’s about the future of an industry that has the potential to fundamentally change how we interact with financial systems. It’s about ensuring that the U.S. remains a global leader in technological innovation, rather than stifling that innovation through overly burdensome regulation. If this case is successful, it could provide much-needed clarity and protection for the digital asset industry, allowing it to grow and evolve in a way that remains true to the decentralized principles that make it so transformative. Regulatory clarity brings confidence. Conversely, if the IRS’s rule stands, it could create a chilling effect on innovation. Developers may be forced to comply with unreasonable requirements that not only slow down progress but potentially push talented teams and entrepreneurs to more forward-thinking jurisdictions (where, believe me, they will be welcomed with open arms!). We could see a repeat of what happened in other sectors, where regulatory uncertainty led to a drain of talent and investment. For the U.S., ceding this leadership would be a strategic disaster. This lawsuit is not just about a single rule; it’s about defining the future of financial innovation in a rapidly changing world. How we choose to regulate DeFi, blockchain, and other emerging technologies will shape the trajectory of the digital economy for years to come. This legal battle may very well determine whether the U.S. continues to be a leader in innovation or whether we risk falling behind in the race to define the future of finance. If regulators insist on ploughing ahead with their heavy-handed law, they’ll have an almighty fight on their hands. They may find out what many others also learned the hard way: Don’t mess with Texas. At its core, this dispute highlights a deeper question around innovation. How can governments regulate technologies that challenge traditional models of control and centralization? Striking the right balance between oversight and innovation is crucial not just for DeFi but for all emerging technologies. The outcome of this case will set a precedent for how the U.S. approaches regulation in the digital economy. Will the courts uphold the rule, potentially stifling a sector with transformative potential? Or will they rein in regulatory overreach, paving the way for a more innovation-friendly environment? As stakeholders on both sides prepare for what promises to be a landmark legal battle, the stakes for the future of decentralized finance—and America’s role in it—could not be higher. title: How the EU Can Scale Up Carbon Removal
description: The European Union’s compliance and voluntary carbon markets, as they currently stand, cannot sustainably fund carbon-removal technologies. But policymakers can use regulation, such as requiring firms to purchase negative emissions credits, to promote investm…
content: The European Unions compliance and voluntary carbon markets, as they currently stand, cannot sustainably fund carbon-removal technologies. But policymakers can use regulation, such as requiring firms… [+6423 chars]
full_text:
The European Union’s compliance and voluntary carbon markets, as they currently stand, cannot sustainably fund carbon-removal technologies. But policymakers can use regulation, such as requiring firms to purchase negative emissions credits, to promote investment and deployment of this green solution across the bloc.  BERLIN/PARIS – The European Union has committed to achieving net-zero greenhouse-gas (GHG) emissions by 2050, and there are strong signals that EU policymakers will approve a new target to reduce emissions by 90% by 2040. The science is clear on what must be done to limit global warming to 1.5º Celsius above preindustrial levels: rapid and dramatic cuts in emissions and the removal of 6-10 gigatons of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere annually. And yet the former receives far more attention than the latter.   This must change – and fast. Removal of atmospheric CO2 will require scaling up investment in carbon-removal technologies from $5-13 billion today to $6-16 trillion by 2050. For comparison, this is at least double the amount of revenues generated by the oil and gas industry each year.   Setting aside the moral – one could say existential – obligation to protect the climate, there is a business case for deploying carbon-removal technology across the EU. By 2050, a global carbon-removal industry capable of achieving net-zero emissions could be worth between $300 billion and $1.2 trillion.   Besides private- and public-sector investments, carbon markets – where companies purchase credits to offset their emissions – have emerged as one of the most important sources of finance for carbon-removal projects. By putting a price on carbon, businesses are incentivized to improve energy efficiency and develop and deploy green solutions across their operations.   Today, there are two main approaches to carbon pricing: compliance and voluntary carbon markets. The compliance market is regulated by mandatory carbon-reduction regimes, mainly targeting high-emitting industries such as steel, oil, and transportation, while the voluntary market operates independently, without direct regulatory oversight.   The EU’s Emissions Trading System (ETS), the bloc’s compliance market, works on a cap-and-trade principle, whereby firms in specific sectors receive emission allowances, the supply of which is capped at a level that reduces total CO2 emissions. They can sell unused allowances on the market, often to companies that require additional ones.   By contrast, voluntary carbon markets allow businesses and individuals to purchase credits from verified offset projects in order to meet sustainability goals independently from any emission allowances. These markets use different methodologies to ensure that the emissions reductions are real, measurable, and permanent.   Unfortunately, despite the urgency of climate action, recent debates about voluntary carbon markets have cast doubt on their usefulness. Skeptics argue that the lack of transparency and inconsistent standards lead to low-quality credits based on offsets that fail to deliver the promised emissions reductions. In their view, these markets allow large companies to engage in a sophisticated form of greenwashing.   The controversy came to a head earlier this year, when naysayers questioned the legitimacy of the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi), which develops the global standards and tools that enable companies to set GHG targets in line with reaching net-zero emissions by 2050. The SBTi’s decision to allow firms to include voluntary carbon credits in the calculation of their indirect emissions triggered a significant backlash, with many challenging the credibility of such instruments. A few months later, the SBTi revised its position, clarifying that environmental attribute certificates – including carbon credits – cannot be used to offset a company’s value-chain emissions.   These developments have held up critical financing for climate solutions – especially carbon removal. Neither the EU ETS nor the bloc’s voluntary carbon markets can sustainably fund carbon-removal technologies. Many have suggested using advanced technology to improve the transparency and accountability of carbon markets. But given the situation’s complexity and the lack of unified voluntary standards, scaling up carbon removal requires another tool: regulation.   Japan serves as a good example. The country’s compliance carbon market now accepts credits from carbon-removal methods, including direct air capture and bioenergy carbon capture and storage. California’s Carbon Dioxide Removal Market Development Act could likewise foster the widespread adoption and deployment of this technology by defining which types of emissions it can counterbalance.   The EU should require companies to reduce emissions to a certain threshold and purchase “negative emissions credits” to compensate for their remaining climate impact. Equally important, clear rules for certifying carbon-removal practices to ensure their effectiveness and long-term storage will incentivize businesses to invest in these technologies.   Some progress has already been made. The EU’s adoption of the carbon removals certification framework this year was an important first step toward regulating this technology.   But more must be done. For starters, it is unclear how this new framework will work with existing regulations, including the ETS. Moreover, standards-setting organizations such as the SBTi must better integrate “beyond value chain mitigation” – a firm’s efforts to reduce GHG emissions outside of its own business activities – and carbon removal into short-term corporate climate targets to help guide the regulatory response. As the EU prepares to revise the ETS in 2026, it must take advantage of this opportunity to take the lead in promoting a crucial green technology.  Disclosure: The authors of this article are, respectively, the CEO of a company that certifies credits for voluntary carbon markets and an investor with a stake in the company.
